answers.answer: Hi!Well, yes, a compressed (pinched) or damaged nerve can cause muscle loss, numbness, fasciculations and loss of function of a part or limb. However there are many other causes of muscle loss.Liver diseases, hyperthyroidism and weight loss, diabetes, ALS (but this has upper motor neuron signs), Charcot Marie Tooth syndrome, multiple sclerosis, Guillain-Barre syndrome, myotonia congenita, muscular dystrophy, and myotonic dystrophy could be the cause of muscle wasting.If your doctor has ruled out these causes, then yes, going for surgery that lifts the compression on the nerves can improve muscle wasting and loss. Post surgery you will need rigorous rehabilitation and physiotherapy to build up muscle mass. Please discuss all this with your treating doctor. Take care!
